conclusion: To determine when objects A and B are farthest apart, analyze their velocity-time graphs.
The distance between the two objects is the difference in their positions, found by integrating their velocity functions over time.
Object A has a constant positive velocity, represented by a straight line.
Object B has a velocity that changes over time, represented by a curve.
For Object A, the position function is a linear function of time due to constant velocity.
For Object B, the position function is the area under the curve of its velocity-time graph.
The distance between the two objects at any time t is the absolute difference between their positions.
The maximum distance occurs when the difference in positions is greatest, corresponding to the largest area between the two curves.
At t1, Object B starts moving in the opposite direction, increasing the distance from Object A.
At t2, Object B changes direction again, moving towards Object A.
The maximum distance occurs just before t2, when Object B is moving away from Object A at the greatest rate.
The two objects are farthest apart at time t1, when the area between the curves is the largest.
The two objects are farthest apart at time t1.
